content: The FY2015 homeland security appropriations reflected major actions taken, with the Administration requesting $38.332 billion for DHS, a decrease from the previous year. The overall estimated DHS budget for FY2015 increased slightly compared to FY2014. The House Committee on Appropriations reported its version of the FY2015 DHS Appropriations bill in June 2014. The House Committee on Appropriations reported its version of the FY2015 DHS Appropriations bill in June 2014, providing a net discretionary appropriation of $39,220 million for DHS for FY2015. This amount was $888 million (2.3%) above the Administration's request and $50 million (0.1%) below the amount provided under Division F of P.L. 113-76. The Senate Committee on Appropriations also reported its version of the FY2015 DHS Appropriations bill in June 2014. The Senate-reported S. 2534 bill provided a net discretionary appropriation of $39,000 million for DHS for FY2015, excluding funds for disaster relief and Coast Guard overseas operations. The bill was $668 million (1.7%) above the Administration's request and $270 million (0.7%) below the amount provided in P.L. 113-76. H.J.Res. 124, a Continuing Appropriations Resolution, 2015, was introduced to fund the federal government until full-year appropriations were passed. The government was funded through a joint resolution until December 11, 2014, or until full-year appropriations were passed. The Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015, was signed into law on December 16, 2014, but did not include full annual funding for DHS due to disagreements over immigration-related executive actions. Division L of H.R. 83 was a key component in this funding issue. Division L of H.R. 83 extended FY2015 funding for DHS through February 27, 2015. H.R. 240, a bill providing $39.7 billion for DHS, was introduced but not reported out of committee. Five amendments were made under a structured rule, including "Sense of Congress" amendments on immigration policy. Three amendments were proposed to restrict the use of federal funds for the Administration's immigration policies, including prohibiting funds for implementing certain directives and granting federal benefits to aliens. The House passed a bill on January 14, 2015, with five amendments restricting federal funds for DACA applications and prioritizing deportation for aliens convicted of specific offenses. The Senate adopted a similar amendment on February 27, 2015, and passed the bill by a vote of 68-31. On February 27, 2015, a three-week extension of the continuing resolution funding DHS (H.J.Res. 35) did not pass the House by a vote of 203-224. The Senate then amended a House bill (H.R. 33) to extend the resolution through March 6, 2015, which was later signed into law as P.L. 114-3. On March 3, 2015, the House approved the Senate version of H.R. 240 by a vote of 257-167, and it was signed into law as P.L. 114-4 on March 4, 2015. Title III includes appropriations for National Protection and Programs Directorate, Office of Health Affairs, and Federal Emergency Management Agency. Title IV includes appropriations for U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, Science and Technology Directorate, and Federal Law Enforcement Training Center. Title V contains general provisions providing congressional direction to the department.
